climbs.name: Violent Green Swallow
climbs.fa: Dean Brault, Eric Fazio-Rhicard, and/or Jim Scott

content.description: Pocket-pulling through the first few bolts leads to thoughtful moves on slightly smaller holds.  Venturing slightly to the left and right between clips keeps the route at grade.
content.location: Furthest left route on the West-facing wall.  The route can be identified since it is the only mild sport route in the vicinity.

content.description: A bit steeper than routes to the right, with 3 crux bits to keep it interesting.
content.location: 15 feet left of Kopytem sem, Kopytem tam

content.description: A thought provoking route following a discontinuous crack for a little while. There are some spooky blocks up high. Interesting rock and impressive features.
content.location: Locate large boulder to left of where trail meets the main wall. This route starts behind the boulder next to a 'shark fin' flake.

content.description: This route includes an obvious right facing dihedral.  It's easy to get off-route on this one; don't necessarily follow the path of least resistance.  Tons of friction on small jibs, sharp edges on holds.  Look around for the jugs, there are plenty.  Belayer beware: there is LOOSE ROCK as this route is pretty new (2/2/07).
content.protection: Bolts, shared ring anchors w/Mustang Sally.
content.location: This route is the second bolted line to the left of the bolder (just right of Mustang Sally, which climbs the mini-roof).

content.description: The first part of the route is moderate.  Once you get to the height of the bottom of the "saddle", it gets steeper and harder.  There is a sustained series 5.11 moves as the route moves around the saddle.  You better have tough tips because the rock gets rough on top.  My 57 meter rope barely reached the ground.
content.location: Just to the left of an enormous hole halfway up the cliff that looks like the top a saddle turned 90 degrees.  It is on the route map.

content.description:
Long and sustained. Lots of variety, crimps, underclings, sidepulls, pinches, jugs, slopey stuff, little pockets, huge pockets, and one shaped like a big bull penis. This climb has it all. 

  There is a distinct crux near the top. I think it was between the last two bolts. Thin moves there. 

  A 60 meter barely reaches with rope stretch. I think My rope might be short for 60M though...
content.location: 2nd route from the right in a little cove about 100ft up from where the trail deposits you by Beeware. Starts on a nice ledge.

climbs.name: Nova Super Sport
climbs.fa: Eric Rhicard, Jim Scott, Dean Brault

content.description: Steep climbing for the area. Many deep pockets and good edges make for fun climbing. Try not to burn too much rubber off the line, you'll need it to cross the finish.
content.location: Start about 50ft left of large pod close to the ground. This is the left of the two gently overhanging routes.

climbs.name: No Mas Boot
climbs.fa: Dean Brault, Eric Fazio-Rhicard, and/or Jim Scott

content.description:
No Mas Boot begins with twenty feet of less-than-vertical featured face protected by the odd, small weakness.  From here ascend a series of large, somewhat grungy pods.  Clip the lone bolt before face climbing to the anchors. 

  Personally I found the climbing enjoyable but the rock questionable for gear placements.  There were ample placements but I had trouble trusting them.
content.protection:
Gear, 1 Bolt, Ring Chains. 

  A rack spanning small cams, such as C3s, to 2" seemed sufficient.  I carried doubles but depending on comfort level and creativity that may be overkill.
content.location: No Mas Boot is the third route from the right.  It climbs the largest weaknesses in the sector and can be spotted by the lone bolt above the highest pod.  The anchors are shared with Men In Funny Hats.

content.description: Can be done in 2 pitches, but since P1 is cruiser 5.8+ at best you better should do it in only 1.  Upper 1/3 is great climbing, but unfortunately doesn't last long enough.
content.protection: Lots o' bolts w/ring anchors after each pitch.
content.location: Just left of DMB, where the south face starts to become a west face.  Double rope rappel, or rap to anchors of P1, then again to the ground.

content.description: Outstanding rock quality and really fun climbing. This is definitely worth doing.
content.location: About 50ft left of the boulder, there is a strange hole in the wall that goes down below ground level. The route goes through an obvious mini-roof around the 2nd bolt.

climbs.name: Mojo
climbs.fa: Dean Brault, Eric Fazio-Rhicard, and/or Jim Scott

content.description:
This route climbs better than it looks.  The gear placements are solid from good stances. 

  There are a few shrubs on or near the route for atmosphere.  Watch out for the shedding cholla to the left at the base.
content.protection: BGC - 4 Bolts, Nuts & Cams To #2, Shares Anchors with "Lung Biscuit".
content.location: Located between "Lung Biscuit" and "Violent Green Swallow" on the left (West) side of the Mustang.

content.description: Face climbing and one bulgy section. Wait for very cold (and preferably breezy) day due to bees on "Beeware" next door.
Follow a wavey, white streak up good rock with nice pods and edges. A very nice route, despite the blocks high on the route. I'm sure they're solid but they sound funky.
content.location: Very near where the trail meets the main wall, a little bit to the right, locate a tan scar with a white streak above it. Follow a bolted line up left streak.

climbs.name: Kopytem Sem Kopytem Tam (Hoof here, Hoof there)

content.description: Varied climbing that starts in a short handcrack.    Engaging right to the final mantle onto a large ledge.     Somewhat wandering (hence the name)
content.location: 10th route left of Beeware.  Look for a 10 foot hand crack that starts at the ground with a bolt near the top

content.description: First half is 5.8, not-so-great.  Second half is committing, fun, and will put hair on your chest, be you a man or woman.
content.protection: Ring anchors @ top + lots of bolts.  Bring all the draws you got.
content.location: Just before the "corner" where the south face starts to curve and become a west face.  Either double rope rappel, or rap. to P1 anchors of New Safari (from end of DMB: about 100' down and 15' left).

content.description: Crazy holds! The crux on this route may be trying to decide which of the thousands of pebbles to choose from.
content.location: Second bolted route left of boulder. Goes up through shallow yellow right facing corner.

content.description: Thin face climbing that goes on and on with the exception of one little ledge with thin holds that make getting on it then moving right on it a bit awkward.
content.location: Just left of Left Y Line.  Starts up a section with some finger locks then continues straight up until you are under the right side of the roof.

content.description: The first pitch felt like harder 5.10.  It goes up a dihedral-like feature.  At the anchors, continue left.  (If you go right, you will be on Fuerte Vaquero and it looks a lot harder.)  The route gets steeper and there is a section of 3 or 4 bolts that is fairly sustained.  There is great climbing here with many pockets of various sizes.  This route can be climbed as two pitches or one long one.
content.location: to the left of an enormous chimney/cave formation on the west side of the crag, see topo

content.description: The name says it all. There is a bee-hive in the first big hole (3rd bolt). This route should be very good once the bees are gone. If you do get on it, try to be quiet.
content.location: First route when counting from the right. Starts at a low overhang.

content.description: The Mustang is a south facing limestone crag. Currently there are 27 routes from 5.8 to 5.12.   Most are sport, but 5 routes do require a light rack. Routes are from 90 to 200 feet long.  All routes can be climbed and rapped on a 60 meter rope.    Most routes are slightly off vertical with churt edges and occasional holes and pockets.    Almost a mile long with an average height of 200 feet the new route potential is enormous!!!
